stem: The pediatric nurse is assessing the developmental stage of two children in the clinic. Based on the documentation, match each behavior with the correct developmental period.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient 1 (Ava, 5 years old): Starting kindergarten. Enjoys playing 'house' and dressing up. Often asks 'Why?' about everything.
Patient 2 (Leo, 8 years old): Active in a local soccer league. Proudly shows the nurse a collection of baseball cards he has organized by team.

tabs.title: Developmental Information
tabs.content:

tabs.title: Physical Assessment
tabs.content:
Ava (5): Rides a bicycle with training wheels. Can tie her shoelaces.
Leo (8): Enjoys team sports. Is developing a sense of 'fairness' and rules.

rows.text: Magical thinking and believing toys have feelings (animism).
Understanding conservation (mass/volume stay the same in different shapes).
Developing industry through competence in school and sports.
Imaginative play where roles are acted out (e.g., playing school).
Focusing on peer groups and following complex game rules.

rationale.correct: Preschoolers (c1) are in the pre-operational stage characterized by magical thinking (r1) and imaginative play (r4). School-age children (c2) transition to concrete operations, understanding concepts like conservation (r2), and focus on competence/industry through rules and peer groups (r3, r5).
clinicalPearls: Industry vs. Inferiority: School-age children want to be good at things.
Conservation: If you pour juice from a tall glass to a wide one, an 8-year-old knows it's the same amount; a 5-year-old thinks the tall one has 'more'.
Magical thinking typically ends around age 6.

questionTrap.trap: Believing that an 8-year-old still engages in magical thinking.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: By age 7-8, children are in the concrete operational stage—they need facts and logic, not magic.

mnemonic.title: Industry equals Interest
mnemonic.expansion: School-age children have an **Industry** for **Interests** (collections, sports, rules).
